factbox.description: During the 2003 heat wave in Europe, about 70,000 people died, mostly elderly. According to scientists who study ancient tree rings, it was the region’s hottest heat wave in 2,500 years.

nodes.description: Extreme heat waves could become longer and more severe
In regions lacking air conditioning, Thousands of people, particularly the elderly, could die
Reduced rainfall causes soil to dry out, reducing crop yields
Extreme heat increases evaporation, further drying the soil
Poor harvests could cause food shortages and temporary price increases

factbox.description: A series of droughts between 2006 and 2011 devastated rural areas in Syria. Unemployed refugees fled to the cities, contributing to political instability, civil war and disputes over refugees in Europe.

nodes.description: Rising temperatures could cause more numerous, widespread and persistent droughts
Reduced crop yields could cause localized famines
People could flee droughtstricken areas to become “climate refugees”
Conflicts over resources could fuel political instability and violence

factbox.description: Parts of Argentina have already seen a surge of malaria as the climate warms.

nodes.description: Yellow fever, Chagas’s disease, schistosomiasis and other warm-weather diseases could all become more common
Lyme disease could spread as ticks’ ranges expand
Toxic algal blooms could contaminate seafood
Mosquitoes could spread malaria and dengue fever to more places
Waterborne diseases such as cholera could spread as flooding and rain runoff contaminate water supplies
